text: Psalm 108
Prayer to Yahweh for Victory over Enemies
A song. A psalm of David.\f + \fr Ps 108 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one \f*
My heart \add is\add* steadfast, O God.
I will sing and give praise, even \add with\add* my glory.
Awake, harp and lyre.
I will awake \add the\add* dawn.\f + \fr 108:2 \ft Or “I will awake at dawn” \f*
I will give you thanks among the peoples, O Yahweh;
I will give you praise among the nations,
because your loyal love \add is\add* great above \add the\add* heavens,
and your faithfulness \add reaches\add* to \add the\add* clouds.
Be exalted above \add the\add* heavens, O God,
and \add let\add* your glory \add be\add* above all the earth,
so that your beloved ones may be rescued.
Save by your right hand and answer me.
God has spoken in his holiness,
“I will exult, I will divide up Shechem,
and portion out the valley of Succoth.
Gilead \add is\add* mine. Manasseh \add is\add* mine.
And Ephraim \add is\add* the ⸤helmet for⸥\f + \fr 108:8 \ft Literally “protection of” \f* my head.
Judah \add is\add* my scepter;\f + \fr 108:8 \ft Or “commander’s rod” \f*
Moab \add is\add* my washing pot.
Over Edom I will cast my sandal;
Over Philistia I will shout in triumph.”
Who will bring me to \add the\add* fortified city?
Who will lead me to Edom?
Have you not rejected us, O God,
and not gone out with our armies, O God?
Give us help against \add the\add* enemy,
for the help of humankind \add is\add* futile.
Through God we will do valiantly,\f + \fr 108:13 \ft Hebrew “do might” \f*
and \add it is\add* he \add who\add* will tread down our enemies.
